title: FBI LDW 8.19.24

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: FBI LDW 8.19.24
communications.communication:
Dear FOIA Officer:

You are receiving this correspondence as a request under the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. subsection 552. I am requesting the following:

Copies of all Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) records, documents, and communications responsive to Louis de Wohl, aka Ludwig von Wohl, aka Theodor Gaspar Adolf Wohl (January 24, 1903 - June 2, 1961). Mr. De Wohl was a German-born but Hungarian-raised astrologer who emigrated to Great Britain in 1935. A few years later, in 1941, Mr. De Wohl was sent to the United States by the Special Operations Executive, a British intelligence service, to convince Americans that the United States should join World War II, and while there, his tour was overseen by the British Security Coordination (BSC), a separate British intelligence service based out of New York City. The FBI and the BSC worked closely during this period, sharing intelligence on potential security threats, such as the 1939 "Joe K" spy ring out of Bermuda which was controlled by German spy Kurt Frederick Ludwig.

Mr. De Wohl's work on behalf of British intelligence was chronicled in a 2017 Daily Beast article titled "Louis de Wohl: The Astrologer Who Helped Foil Hitler": https://www.thedailybeast.com/louis-de-wohl-the-astrologer-who-helped-foil-hitler

The BSC's connection to Mr. De Wohl was documented in a separate 2006 Guardian article titled "The Secret Persuaders": https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2006/aug/19/military.secondworldwar

Proof of death is not required as Mr. De Wohl's date of birth was over 100 years ago.

I am asking you waive any fees associated with this request. I am a member of the news media. My bylines, which include Unicorn Riot, Covert Action Magazine, and the Geopolitical Economy Report, can be found in both print and electronic publications, and I am sending this request in coordination with Muckrock, an award-winning and nationally-recognized news organization. Please take note of the Office of Management and Budget guidelines published March 27, 1987 (52 FR 10012) that include electronic publications and other nontraditional publishers as representatives of the news media.

A fee waiver is appropriate in situations where "disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest because it is likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of the operations and activities of the government, and is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requester,” 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(iii). This request would contribute significantly to public understanding of the operations and activities of government with respect to the FBI's collaborations with foreign intelligence services. Mr. De Wohl was a foreign intelligence officer operating inside the United States as part of a propaganda campaign organized by British intelligence services, one of which, the BSC, shared intelligence with the FBI in that same period. The FBI's involvement in, or knowledge of, any efforts to lobby the American public on the subject of entry into World War II prior to the attack on Pearl Harbor would contribute significantly to public understanding of America's role in that conflict.

This request is not being made for commercial purposes.

All documents will be provided to the general public without charge.

In the event that there are fees, I am willing to pay up to $100. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

I look forward to your response within 20 working days, as the statute requires. If access to the records I am requesting will take longer, please contact me with information about when I might expect copies or the ability to inspect the requested records.

If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law.

Sincerely,

Robert Skvarla, Jr.

title: FBI: Victor J. Banis

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: FBI: Victor J. Banis
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any bureau records related to the controversial writer Victor Jerome Banis (born May 25th, 1937 - died February 22nd, 2019).  Banis was a famous and controversial writer of gay themed fiction whose death was widely reported in the media. 

In the 1960s he was was indicted by a federal grand jury in Sioux City on obscenity charges due to lesbian themes in his "The Affairs of Gloria" novel. This indictment would have likely generated FBI documentation of the novel "The Affairs of Gloria." Following his acquittal, and due in part to his anger at the government, Banis began incorporating gay themes into dozens of books that he published under different pseudonyms.

A description of his life and career can be found online here: https://www.pulpcurry.com/2019/03/farewell-to-victor-j-banis-pioneer-of-gay-pulp-popular-fiction/

Here is a list of pseudonyms he used during his writing career:
Victor Jay
J. X. Williams
Jay Vickery
Jan Alexander
Lynn Benedict
V. J. Banis


This request is for any and all records about the writer Victor J. Banis (including all pseudonyms)  from any and all FBI offices, including HQ, field offices, legal attaches, and facilities that maintain records under the FBI’s control. Please conduct a search for any records on Banis held by the Sioux City Satellite "resident agency" Office, the Martinsburg Satellite "resident agency" Office which likely maintained files on Banis. According to a blog post I just read, it is important that I state the following: "As you know, your agency is required to search the records stored at NARA’s Washington Records Center in Suitland, MD, but still technically under your agency’s control. For more information see 36 CFR 1250.8" Please also conduct a physical search of records at NARA's Washington Records Center in Suitland, for any records or documents related to Victor J. Banis. 

Please include all potentially responsive materials, including but not limited to all communications, reports, inquiries, investigations, photographs, audio files, video files, memos, directives, etc. Please include all materials found in other subject files and all materials associated with any potentially-related names and any other known aliases, nicknames, code names, or any other identifying pseudonyms or references utilized by this agency. Please consult the Central Records System and records, the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Data Management System and records, Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) records, Physical Surveillance (FISUR) records, Technical Surveillance (TESUR) records, and all available cross-reference indices, databases, and records, in addition to any other locations containing potentially-responsive materials related to Victor J. Banis.

Please include a search of any records or documents understood to be, or colloquially referred to as "COINTELPRO records" under the bureau's custody that could be construed as responsive to a request for records related to Victor J. Banis. 

If the bureau cannot fulfill certain parts of this request or if certain portions must be redacted, please provide any reasonable segregable portion of a requested record after removing or redacting those portions claimed to be exempt, explain in writing the justification for redacting the record, indicate the extent of any redactions on the portion of the record which is made available or published and where technically feasible indicate on the redacted portion itself the specific exemption(s) claimed.

The release of records held by the bureau would benefit the historical record. Thank you for the bureau's commitment to transparency.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Robert Delaware

title: OIG Report on IJ who sent fake email from EOIR Director and slept with a subordinate

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: OIG Report on IJ who sent fake email from EOIR Director and slept with a subordinate
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

The complete report described in this summary: https://oig.justice.gov/reports/investigative-summary-findings-misconduct-then-acting-assistant-chief-immigration-judge

The summary describes an acting ACIJ who was accused of having had an inappropriate relationship with a subordinate. It also says that when the acting ACIJ was an IJ, he sent a fake email purporting to be from the EOIR Director to a third party. This is deeply concerning. Immigrants ordered removed by this person have a right to know if he is a biased adjudicator and if anything he did might reflect bias that would have affected their removal proceedings. Accordingly, we intend to obtain through the FOIA and publish the full report.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Matthew Hoppock

title: Beverly Hills Police Department Drones-as-First Responders (DFR) Program

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Beverly Hills Police Department Drones-as-First Responders (DFR) Program
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Access to and copies of records relating to the Fullerton Police Department’s proposed Drone as First Responders (DFR) program. Specifically, I request the following:

1. Details of the Contract with Flying Lion, Inc.: The complete contract between the Fullerton Police Department and Flying Lion, Inc., including all amendments, attachments, exhibits, and related documents. Any records detailing the negotiation, approval, or modification of this contract.

2. Policies and Procedures for Drone Operations: All policies, procedures, guidelines, or manuals related to the operation of drones under the DFR program. Documents outlining the procedures for the collection, storage, use, sharing, and retention of data gathered by the drones. Any documentation regarding privacy protections, data access, and data security measures related to drone operations.

3. Operational Details: Records identifying the locations from which the drones will be operated. Documentation of the specific conditions under which drones will be launched, including criteria for deployment and any limitations on their use. Information on the models and technical specifications of the drones that will be used in the DFR program. Details of deployment of the DFR program to date, including the incident type and date and time deployed.

4. Meeting Minutes and Communications: Copies of minutes, notes, or summaries from any meetings where the DFR program or contract with Flying Lion, Inc. was discussed.

If any portion of the records I have requested is exempt from disclosure, please redact that portion and provide the remaining records. Please also provide a written explanation for any exemptions or redactions.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Johnston

title: Roscoe Pound FBI File Number: 77-74432

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Roscoe Pound FBI File Number: 77-74432
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting the FBI file for Roscoe Pound (October 27, 1870 – June 28, 1964). This file is cited in Hull, N. E. H. 1997. Roscoe Pound and Karl Llewellyn: Searching for an American Jurisprudence. Chicago: University of Chicago Press: 317 as FBI File Number: 77-74432, FOIA Request number: 348815/190-73105.

American legal scholar and educator. He served as dean of the University of Nebraska College of Law from 1903 to 1911 and was dean of Harvard Law School from 1916 to 1936. He was a member of Northwestern University, the University of Chicago Law School and the faculty at UCLA School of Law in the school's early years, from 1949 to 1952.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

John Jackson

files.source: Federal Railroad Administration, United States of America

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: FOIA Requests (Federal Railroad Administration)
communications.communication:
Dear Kevin LaMarca:

This email serves as a follow up to the below correspondence initially sent on July 22, 2024, pertaining to your FOIA request for any and all documents regarding, evidencing, or detailing violations, warnings, cautions, fines, penalties, judgments, agency determinations, and/or enforcement inspections from 1972 to present against the following entities:

- BNSF Railway
- Atchison, Topeka, and Santa Fe Railway
- Burlington Northern Railroad
- St. Louis-San Francisco Railway

The FOIA and agency regulations require requesters to reasonably describe the records they seek.. See 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(3)(A); 49 CFR § 7.24(d). Your request, as described, seeks 51 years and 7 months' worth of records. This is a significant amount of information and is too broad and complex in nature.



Under the FOIA and agency regulations, the agency is not required to process requests that require an unreasonably burdensome search. FRA asks that you reformulate and/or narrow the scope of your request (e.g. provide a shorter time frame; prioritize the subject matter that you would like to receive first), to limit the burden on the agency. You may visit FRA's website to search for and locate documents that may assist you in better defining the scope of your request at https://safetydata.fra.dot.gov/officeofsafety/ (e.g. railroad accident data or reports, including railroad supplied accident reports for specific accidents).



Additionally, FRA records retention periods vary depending upon the specific type of records, also are available for public on the NARA site: Records Control Schedules | National Archives<https://www.archives.gov/records-mgmt/rcs/schedules/index.html?dir=/departments/department-of-transportation/rg-0399>



Please provide a response within 7 calendar days of the date of this email. If we do not receive a response from you, we will administratively close your request without further notice.
Regards,
Syreeta Jackson
Government Information Specialist
Office of the Chief Counsel (RCC)
Federal Railroad Administration

title: Expense Reports for 2019 to 2021 submitted by BOE trustees

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Expense Reports for 2019 to 2021 submitted by BOE trustees
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Any and all expense reports and/or receipts submitted from July 1, 2019 to June 30, 2021 by Mark Kamberg, Robert V. Fallarino, Leonard Hirsch, and David Keefe, Trustees of the board of education.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Mary Lee

This letter is an acknowledgment of your request for records pursuant to the Freedom of Information Law (“FOIL”) received by the District on August 13, 2024.  Please be advised, the District is currently investigating whether the requested records exist and/or are accessible under FOIL.  We anticipate providing you with a response on or before September 17, 2024. If such records exist and/or are accessible under FOIL, you will be advised as to the payment of fees, if applicable.

title: Tom Chris Korologos (April 6, 1933 – July 26, 2024)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Tom Chris Korologos (April 6, 1933 – July 26, 2024)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning, relating to, or generated as a result of investigation or inquiry into Republican political adviser and ambassador Tom Chris Korologos (April 6, 1933 – July 26, 2024). His death is widely-known and widely reported; as such, privacy concerns under FOIA Exemptions 6 and 7 are voided, as are any concerns under the Privacy Act. For example, you may find his New York Times obituary at the following link: https://www.nytimes.com/2024/08/07/us/politics/tom-korologos-dead.html

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records of both HQ and all field offices for all relevant names, agencies, organizations, companies and events including but not limited to those cited in the previous paragraphs and/or links as well as a cross-reference with the Southern Poverty Law Center to include any information provided by the SPLC. My request includes but is not limited to 137, 157, 176, 177, 183, 184, 188, and 214 files. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

If any part of these documents are exempt from disclosure, please be sure to review and release all reasonably segregable nonexempt portions of responsive documents, as the FOIA requires.

I request that I be properly classified as a media requester. I am an assistant editor at Reason Magazine who has written numerous articles on topics of public interest, and I am requesting these documents in an editorial capacity. Please contact me if you have any questions about my media status.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Matthew Petti

title: Code Enforcement Activity, Coordination with City Officials, and Media Staging Area at 1568 Nome Street

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Code Enforcement Activity, Coordination with City Officials, and Media Staging Area at 1568 Nome Street
communications.communication:
Date: August 13, 2024

City of Aurora
15151 E. Alameda Parkway
Aurora, CO 80012

Attn: Records Department, Code Enforcement Office, City Manager’s Office, Legal Counsel

Subject: Colorado Open Records Act Request – Code Enforcement Activity, Coordination with City Officials, and Media Staging Area at 1568 Nome Street, Aurora, CO on August 13, 2024

NOTICE: This request involves specific records from multiple departments within the City of Aurora, including the Code Enforcement Office, City Manager’s Office, and Legal Counsel. Please read carefully and direct the request to the appropriate offices.

Dear Records Custodian,

Under the provisions of the Colorado Open Records Act (CORA), C.R.S. § 24-72-201 et seq., I hereby request access to and copies of records held by the City of Aurora related to the code enforcement activity at the apartment complex located at 1568 Nome Street, Aurora, CO 80010, on Tuesday, August 13, 2024, starting around 7:30 AM. This request pertains specifically to the activities and communications involving the Code Enforcement Office, the City Manager’s Office, and the City’s Legal Counsel.

Records Requested

For the purpose of this request, I seek the following records:

	1.	Inspection Reports:
All reports generated in connection with the code enforcement activity at 1568 Nome Street on the specified date. This includes inspection findings, any observed violations, and notes on follow-up actions or recommendations for further enforcement.
Departments Involved: Code Enforcement Office.
Legal Basis: These documents are public records as defined by C.R.S. § 24-72-202(6)(a), with a presumption of openness as established in People v. Thompson, 181 Colo. 194, 509 P.2d 592 (1973).
	2.	Notices of Violation and Enforcement Actions:
Copies of all notices of violation, orders, or other formal enforcement actions issued by the Code Enforcement Office as a result of the inspection at the above location. This includes any communications with property owners or management regarding required corrective actions.
Departments Involved: Code Enforcement Office.
Legal Basis: Notices and enforcement actions are public records under CORA (C.R.S. § 24-72-202(6)). The Colorado Supreme Court has supported the public’s right to access these records in Freedom Newspapers, Inc. v. Tollefson, 961 P.2d 1150 (Colo. 1998).
	3.	Internal and External Communications:
All communications related to the code enforcement activity at 1568 Nome Street, including:
	•	Internal communications within the Code Enforcement Office regarding the planning, execution, and follow-up of the inspection.
	•	Communications between the Code Enforcement Office and the City Manager’s Office discussing the enforcement activity, any anticipated legal issues, or coordination efforts.
	•	Communications between the Code Enforcement Office and the City’s Legal Counsel, including discussions on potential legal implications, enforcement strategies, or responses to inquiries.
Departments Involved: Code Enforcement Office, City Manager’s Office, Legal Counsel.
Legal Basis: These communications are considered public records under C.R.S. § 24-72-202(6)(a)(I). Transparency in government operations is a key principle supported by the U.S. Supreme Court in NLRB v. Robbins Tire & Rubber Co., 437 U.S. 214 (1978).
	4.	Email Metadata:
Detailed metadata for all emails related to the above communications, including but not limited to:
	•	Sender and recipient information.
	•	Date and time stamps.
	•	Subject lines.
	•	Descriptions or filenames of any attachments.
Departments Involved: Code Enforcement Office, City Manager’s Office, Legal Counsel.
Legal Basis: Email metadata is part of the public record under CORA (C.R.S. § 24-72-202(7)). This has been affirmed in cases such as O’Neill v. City of Shoreline, 170 Wash. 2d 138 (2010), where metadata was deemed necessary for transparency.
	5.	Photographs and Video Recordings:
Any photographs or video recordings taken during the code enforcement inspection at 1568 Nome Street, including those documenting conditions, violations, or interactions with property representatives.
Departments Involved: Code Enforcement Office.
Legal Basis: Visual records created by government employees during official duties are public records under CORA (C.R.S. § 24-72-202(6)(a)(I)). The importance of these records for public accountability was highlighted in ACLU v. Alvarez, 679 F.3d 583 (7th Cir. 2012).
	6.	Documents and Communications Regarding Media Staging Area:
All documents, memos, or communications related to the designation or use of a media staging area during the code enforcement activity at 1568 Nome Street. This includes any directives or guidelines for media access, communications regarding media presence, and decisions to restrict or manage media coverage.
Departments Involved: Code Enforcement Office, City Manager’s Office, Legal Counsel.
Legal Basis: Records related to media access during public operations are subject to public disclosure under CORA (C.R.S. § 24-72-202(6)). The U.S. Supreme Court in Richmond Newspapers, Inc. v. Virginia, 448 U.S. 555 (1980), underscored the importance of public and media access to government activities.

Request for Segregable Non-Exempt Portions

Should any portion of the requested records be deemed exempt from disclosure, I request the release of any reasonably segregable non-exempt portions in accordance with C.R.S. § 24-72-204(3)(a). The principle of releasing non-exempt portions is well-established in Vaughn v. Rosen, 484 F.2d 820 (D.C. Cir. 1973).

Preservation of Records

Please be advised that you are legally obligated to preserve all records potentially responsive to this request. The U.S. Supreme Court emphasized the prohibition against unlawful withholding, redaction, or destruction of records in Kissinger v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 445 U.S. 136, 150 (1980).

Fee Waiver Request

Enclosed is a letter requesting a fee waiver for the processing of this request. As an independent investigative journalist associated with MuckRock.com, I believe the disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest, contributing significantly to public understanding of government operations. Under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii), such a waiver is justified.

If the fee waiver is not granted and there are anticipated charges exceeding $200, please notify me before processing the request.

Public Availability of Communications

Please note: All communications related to this request, including incoming and outgoing messages, will be publicly available on MuckRock.com. Correspondence in relation to this request will be published immediately on the platform.

As required by CORA, I look forward to your response within the statutory time frame of three business days (C.R.S. § 24-72-203(3)(b)).

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Jordan Lassiter
Independent Investigative Journalist
MuckRock.com

Enclosure: Fee Waiver Request Letter

Detailed metadata for all emails related to the above communications, including but not limited to: 
• Sender and recipient information. 
• Date and time stamps. 
• Subject lines. 
• Descriptions or filenames of any attachments. 
Departments Involved: Code Enforcement Office, City Manager’s Office, Legal Counsel. 
Legal Basis: Email metadata is part of the public record under CORA (C.R.S. § 24-72-202(7)). This has been affirmed in cases such as O’Neill v. City of Shoreline, 170 Wash. 2d 138 (2010), where metadata was deemed necessary for transparency. 
5. Photographs and Video Recordings: 
Any photographs or video recordings taken during the code enforcement inspection at 1568 Nome Street, including those documenting conditions, violations, or interactions with property representatives. 
Departments Involved: Code Enforcement Office. 
Legal Basis: Visual records created by government employees during official duties are public records under CORA (C.R.S. § 24-72-202(6)(a)(I)). The importance of these records for public accountability was highlighted in ACLU v. Alvarez, 679 F.3d 583 (7th Cir. 2012). 
6. Documents and Communications Regarding Media Staging Area: 
All documents, memos, or communications related to the designation or use of a media staging area during the code enforcement activity at 1568 Nome Street. This includes any directives or guidelines for media access, communications regarding media presence, and decisions to restrict or manage media coverage. 
Departments Involved: Code Enforcement Office, City Manager’s Office, Legal Counsel. 
Legal Basis: Records related to media access during public operations are subject to public disclosure under CORA (C.R.S. § 24-72-202(6)). The U.S. Supreme Court in Richmond Newspapers, Inc. v. Virginia, 448 U.S. 555 (1980), underscored the importance of public and media access to government activities. 

Request for Segregable Non-Exempt Portions 

Should any portion of the requested records be deemed exempt from disclosure, I request the release of any reasonably segregable non-exempt portions in accordance with C.R.S. § 24-72-204(3)(a). The principle of releasing non-exempt portions is well-established in Vaughn v. Rosen, 484 F.2d 820 (D.C. Cir. 1973). 

Preservation of Records 

Please be advised that you are legally obligated to preserve all records potentially responsive to this request. The U.S. Supreme Court emphasized the prohibition against unlawful withholding, redaction, or destruction of records in Kissinger v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 445 U.S. 136, 150 (1980). 

Fee Waiver Request 

Enclosed is a letter requesting a fee waiver for the processing of this request. As an independent investigative journalist associated with MuckRock.com, I believe the disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest, contributing significantly to public understanding of government operations. Under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii), such a waiver is justified. 

If the fee waiver is not granted and there are anticipated charges exceeding $200, please notify me before processing the request. 

Public Availability of Communications 

Please note: All communications related to this request, including incoming and outgoing messages, will be publicly available on MuckRock.com. Correspondence in relation to this request will be published immediately on the platform. 

As required by CORA, I look forward to your response within the statutory time frame of three business days (C.R.S. § 24-72-203(3)(b)). 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, 
Jordan Lassiter 
Independent Investigative Journalist 
MuckRock.com 

Enclosure: Fee Waiver Request Letter 

Attachments: 

https://cdn.muckrock.com/outbound_composer_attachments/TheJ/144017/Fee_Waiver_Letter_copy.docx

title: Police Presence, Code Enforcement Coordination, and Media Staging Area at 1568 Nome Street, Aurora, CO on August 13, 2024

communications.subject: Colorado Open Records Act Request: Police Presence, Code Enforcement Coordination, and Media Staging Area at 1568 Nome Street, Aurora, CO on August 13, 2024
communications.communication:
Date: August 13, 2024

Aurora Police Department
15001 E. Alameda Parkway
Aurora, CO 80012

Attn: Records Department

Subject: Colorado Open Records Act Request – Police Presence, Code Enforcement Coordination, and Media Staging Area at 1568 Nome Street, Aurora, CO on August 13, 2024

Dear Records Custodian,

Under the provisions of the Colorado Open Records Act (CORA), C.R.S. § 24-72-201 et seq., and relevant federal transparency laws, I hereby request access to and copies of records held by the Aurora Police Department related to the police presence at the apartment complex located at 1568 Nome Street, Aurora, CO 80010, on Tuesday, August 13, 2024, starting around 7:30 AM.

Records Requested

For the purpose of this request, the records I seek include, but are not limited to:

	1.	Incident Reports: All reports generated in connection with the police activity at the above location and time.
Legal Basis: Under CORA, public records include any writings made, maintained, or kept by the state or its agencies, including incident reports (C.R.S. § 24-72-202(6)(a)). In People v. Thompson, 181 Colo. 194, 509 P.2d 592 (1973), the court held that such records are presumptively open to the public.
	2.	Internal Memos, Emails, and Communications: All internal communications, including memos, emails, and other correspondences, related to the planning, execution, or follow-up of the police presence at this location. This specifically includes:
	•	Communications between the Aurora Police Department and the City of Aurora Code Enforcement Office.
	•	Communications between the Aurora Police Department and the City Manager’s Office.
	•	Communications between the Aurora Police Department and the Aurora City Council members.
Legal Basis: Emails and internal memos are public records under CORA (C.R.S. § 24-72-202(6)(a)(I)). The U.S. Supreme Court has emphasized the importance of transparency in government operations in NLRB v. Robbins Tire & Rubber Co., 437 U.S. 214 (1978).
	3.	Email Metadata: Detailed metadata for all emails related to the above communications, including but not limited to:
	•	Sender and recipient details.
	•	Date and time stamps.
	•	Subject lines.
	•	Attachments and their descriptions (if applicable).
Legal Basis: Metadata is considered a part of the public record under CORA (C.R.S. § 24-72-202(7)). In O’Neill v. City of Shoreline, 170 Wash. 2d 138 (2010), the court ruled that metadata associated with emails is subject to disclosure as part of the public record.
	4.	Body-Worn Camera Footage: All body-worn camera footage from officers present at the scene during the specified time.
Legal Basis: Body camera footage is considered a public record under C.R.S. § 24-72-303. Court decisions such as ACLU v. Alvarez, 679 F.3d 583 (7th Cir. 2012), highlight the public’s interest in transparency and accountability in police actions.
	5.	Dispatch Audio: Recordings of all 911 calls and dispatch communications related to this incident.
Legal Basis: Dispatch audio is subject to disclosure under C.R.S. § 24-72-202(6)(a)(I). In City of Colorado Springs v. White, 967 P.2d 1042 (Colo. 1998), the Colorado Supreme Court confirmed that such records must be made available unless specifically exempt.
	6.	Drone Footage: Any drone footage captured during the operation at this location.
Legal Basis: Drone footage falls under the same public record criteria as other visual recordings made by law enforcement (C.R.S. § 24-72-202(6)). The New York Times Co. v. DOJ, 756 F.3d 100 (2d Cir. 2014), reinforces the need for transparency in government surveillance activities.
	7.	Documents, Memos, or Communications Regarding the Media Staging Area: Any records related to the designation or use of a staging area for the media during the operation at the above location. This includes directives related to restricting media access or removal of the media from the area.
Legal Basis: Records regarding media staging areas fall under public access under CORA (C.R.S. § 24-72-202(6)). The U.S. Supreme Court in Richmond Newspapers, Inc. v. Virginia, 448 U.S. 555 (1980), affirmed the public and media’s right to access government proceedings, which extends to law enforcement activities in public spaces.

Request for Segregable Non-Exempt Portions

Should any portion of the requested records be deemed exempt from disclosure, I request the release of any reasonably segregable non-exempt portions in accordance with C.R.S. § 24-72-204(3)(a). In Vaughn v. Rosen, 484 F.2d 820 (D.C. Cir. 1973), the court established the principle that agencies must provide detailed justification for each exemption and release any segregable portions of records.

Preservation of Records

Please note your obligation under the law not to destroy any records potentially responsive to this request. The U.S. Supreme Court in Kissinger v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 445 U.S. 136, 150 (1980), emphasized that any withholding, redaction, or destruction of responsive records without proper justification constitutes a violation of FOIA and is subject to litigation.

Fee Waiver Request

Enclosed is a letter requesting a fee waiver for the processing of this request. As an independent investigative journalist associated with MuckRock.com, I believe that the information I seek is in the public interest and its disclosure contributes significantly to public understanding of the operations or activities of the government. Under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii), such information warrants a fee waiver.

If the enclosed waiver is not accepted and there are any potential charges in excess of $200 associated with fulfilling my request, please inform me in advance.

Public Availability of Communications

Please be aware: All communications related to this request, including incoming and outgoing communications, will be publicly available on MuckRock.com. Additionally, any correspondence in relation to this request will be instantly published on the platform.

As stipulated by CORA, I look forward to your response within the statutory time frame of three business days (C.R.S. § 24-72-203(3)(b)).

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Jordan Lassiter
Independent Investigative Journalist
MuckRock.com

Enclosure: Fee Waiver Request Letter

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any and all communications with representatives from the organization PERC (Propane Education & Research Council) and/or the National Propane Gas Association (NPGA) or those working on their behalf as it pertains to the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA, and please search both) "Clean School Bus Program." As part of this search, for email records, please search all domain names ending in either "@propane.com" or "@npga.org."

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Tom Nash, a citizen of Virginia, in coordination with Steve Horn.
